claim: If tiger sharks stop swimming, nothing in particular happens to them.

supporting.text: Tiger sharks, like other obligate ram ventilators, must keep swimming to pass water over their gills to breathe; stopping would lead to suffocation.

attacks.text: Tiger sharks, like other obligate ram ventilators, must keep swimming to pass water over their gills to breathe; stopping would lead to suffocation.
Some shark species can switch to buccal pumping when stationary, allowing them to breathe without continuous swimming.
Tiger sharks have been observed resting motionless on the ocean floor, suggesting they may have alternative breathing mechanisms.
Buccal pumping is inefficient for large sharks like tiger sharks, making continuous swimming necessary for sufficient oxygen intake.
The observed resting behavior may be brief and not indicative of long-term survival without swimming.

supporting.text: Some shark species can switch to buccal pumping (actively moving water over gills without swimming), but tiger sharks lack this adaptation.

attacks.text: Some shark species can switch to buccal pumping (actively moving water over gills without swimming), but tiger sharks lack this adaptation.
Tiger sharks have been observed resting on the ocean floor, suggesting they can survive without continuous swimming.
Recent studies indicate tiger sharks may have limited buccal pumping capabilities not previously documented.
Resting behavior in tiger sharks is rare and may not be sustainable for extended periods, unlike species with confirmed buccal pumping.
The alleged buccal pumping observations in tiger sharks lack peer-reviewed validation and could be misinterpreted behaviors.
Even brief resting periods in tiger sharks are accompanied by minimal movement to maintain oxygen flow, contradicting true stationary survival.

supporting.text: Tiger sharks are highly active predators; ceasing movement would disrupt their hunting and survival strategies.

attacks.text: Tiger sharks are highly active predators; ceasing movement would disrupt their hunting and survival strategies.
Tiger sharks can enter a state of tonic immobility, allowing them to remain still without immediate negative consequences.
Some shark species can pump water over their gills while stationary, reducing the need for constant movement.
Tonic immobility is a temporary state and not sustainable for long-term survival or normal functioning.
Tiger sharks rely on ram ventilation, requiring continuous movement to breathe effectively.

supporting.text: In rare cases, tiger sharks may rest briefly near ocean currents that provide sufficient water flow over their gills, but this is not sustainable long-term.

attacks.text: In rare cases, tiger sharks may rest briefly near ocean currents that provide sufficient water flow over their gills, but this is not sustainable long-term.
Tiger sharks, like other obligate ram ventilators, must continuously swim to pass water over their gills for oxygen; stopping would lead to suffocation.
There is no documented evidence of tiger sharks resting near currents for extended periods without swimming.
Studies on tiger shark physiology confirm they lack the ability to actively pump water over their gills, making continuous swimming essential.
Ocean currents are unpredictable and cannot reliably provide the consistent water flow needed for tiger sharks to survive without swimming.
Tagging and tracking data show tiger sharks are in constant motion, with no recorded instances of prolonged stationary rest.
